item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Woman Dies After Stabbing Near Uniqlo in Beijing
item.description: The police said they had arrested the assailant, whom they identified as a 25-year-old man with the surname Gao from the city of Tonghua in Jilin Province.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and MIA LI

item.title: Indonesian Court Overturns Educators’ Convictions in Sexual Abuse Case, Lawyer Says
item.description: The two men, one Canadian and one Indonesian, were convicted in April of sexually assaulting kindergartners, charges their school said had been fabricated.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: An Indonesian appeals court ordered the immediate release of the educators Neil Bantleman, left, and Ferdinand Tjiong, their lawyer said on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Gearing Up and Locking Down Ahead of Victory Parade
item.description: Here are some of the measures that can be expected to affect Beijing residents and visitors in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Paramilitary police and members of a gun salute team at a training session in Beijing this month for the military parade celebrating the end of World War II.

item.title: Conservatives in Myanmar Force Out Leader of Ruling Party
item.description: The party’s leadership did not explain the underlying reasons for the change, but the ouster appeared to be part of a struggle for power.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Thura Shwe Mann, right, was seen as a leading candidate for president in coming elections.

item.title: World Briefing: Azerbaijan: Human Rights Defenders Are Sentenced
item.description: A court on Thursday convicted a human rights defender and her husband on fraud charges, prompting denunciations from rights groups.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Good Times or Bad, Brazil Banks Profit
item.description: With sky-high interest rates for consumers and businesses, favorable government policies and limited competition, Brazil’s banks do well, even when the broader economy is faltering.
item.dc:creator: DAN HORCH
item.media:description: A Banco do Brasil branch in Rio de Janeiro. Even as the economy has stagnated, banks have performed impressively.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scenes From the Deadly Explosions in Tianjin
item.description: When news of the blasts emerged late Wednesday, Chinese turned to social media to post images of the destruction, find updates on casualties and offer support to victims and firefighters tackling the huge blaze.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Debris near the site of the explosions at an industrial area in Tianjin, China, on Thursday.

item.title: Obama Is Set to Discuss Rights Issues With China
item.description: A top State Department official said Thursday that human rights would feature prominently in talks next month between President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: 2 Groups Handled Hostage, Croatia Says
item.description: A Croatian expatriate worker believed to have been beheaded by the Islamic State’s Egyptian affiliate was initially abducted by a different group that demanded a ransom.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Sinai Province of the Islamic State
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: A Secretive Path to Raising U.S. Flag in Cuba
item.description: The story of America’s reconciliation with Cuba is one of near misses, crossed wires and unexpected challenges that could have changed the course of history.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Master Sgt. Kevin Wallace/U.S. Air Force, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Alan P. Gross at Joint Base Andrews in December, after he was released from a Cuban jail after being held for five years.

item.title: U.S. and Turkey Face Questions in Anti-ISIS Effort
item.description: Two weeks after the United States and Turkey announced the plan, it is unclear which forces will fight the jihadists and what support they will receive.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: As Fire Smolders in Tianjin Officials Rush to Stanch Criticism
item.description: Questions loomed over how the toxic chemicals that exploded in fireballs could be stored so close to congested residential areas.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Evacuees lined up for clothes being distributed at a temporary shelter in a school.

item.title: Bangladeshi Women, Isolated in New York City, Need More Support, Advocates Say
item.description: The death of a baby whose mother is accused of throwing him from a window has gripped the social service providers trying to address mental health problems of Bangladeshis.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: China Seeks to Calm Markets as It Devalues Currency for 3rd Consecutive Day
item.description: The renminbi’s official rate against the dollar has fallen 4.4 percent over the last three days, but officials in Beijing said it was not in free fall.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: Studying stock charts on Thursday at a brokerage firm in Shanghai. After two days of declines, the Shanghai composite index rose 1.8 percent on Thursday.

item.title: Study Links Polluted Air in China to 1.6 Million Deaths a Year
item.description: A research group’s findings may complicate the Chinese government’s efforts to clean up the capital city of Beijing ahead of the 2022 Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Waiting on a roadside this month for a highway from Beijing to Hebei Province to reopen after it was closed because of low visibility on a day of heavy smog.

item.title: Message Believed to Be From Qaeda Leader Pledges Support for Taliban
item.description: The voice of Ayman al-Zawahri, who has not had any confirmed audio or video communications since September, was identified in a message acknowledging the Taliban’s new leader.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape
item.description: Claiming the Quran’s support, the Islamic State codifies sex slavery in conquered regions of Iraq and Syria and uses the practice as a recruiting tool.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Letter From Europe: British Media Takes On Calais Migrant Crisis in ‘Silly Season’
item.description: In the summer, when most officials are on vacation, Britain’s newspapers are full of overheated “controversies." The migrant crisis has been a great boon.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants on the French side of the Channel Tunnel last month.

item.title: U.N. Faces Scrutiny Over Unpaid Intern Who Slept in a Tent in Geneva
item.description: The intern who said he could not afford housing in Geneva has called on unpaid interns around the world to unite, and the world body to live up to its own ideals.
item.category: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Venezuela Releases Two Prominent Government Critics From Prison
item.description: The releases of Raúl Baduel and Daniel Ceballos come as the government works to weaken opposition ahead of legislative elections set for December.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: The former mayor of San Cristóbal, Daniel Ceballos, center, looked out from his Caracas apartment with his family on Wednesday. Mr. Ceballos, who had been held on charges related to widespread antigovernment protests last year, was released to house arrest.
